81365899CBDB4032917A4BD05C900D02.description: Evaluate a solution to a complex real world problem based upon prioritized criteria and tradeoffs that account for a range of constraints, including cost, safety, reliability, and aesthetics as well as possible social, cultural, and environmental impacts. [AR Clarification Statement: Use qualitative and quantitative data to analyze a major global challenge for space systems which could include human space travel, terraforming, and colonizing other planets.]

8414C53418D54C57BBA961ECD8BE9518.description: Describe the role of black holes in galactic evolution

F6B74018429A4902BDB3BF0A716ABD25.description: Construct an explanation for galactic structure formation and super massive black holes

193E92038FD542DA8DD458A184F9E848.description: Describe the Limits of Kepler's Law and Newton's Universal Gravitational Law due to Assumptions

BABFBF05D2E74EF9BF6044629080F8C2.description: Identify different parts of a galaxy

BDCC9B94EF924778BDE47BF228998B91.description: Construct an explanation for galactic structure formation and dark matter

7BF5325227854E75ADC0D8EE1EF1CE5E.description: Construct an argument from evidence that the formation of galactic structures depends on a spherical dark matter halo that surrounds a galaxy and supermassive black holes at the center of the galaxy. [Clarification Standard: Emphasis is placed on galactic structures which influence the evolution of the galaxy and influence the rates of star formation in higher density regions of the galaxy.]

742C9E7A1A5F4A698EE891F63FAE3472.description: Explain how the 3 evidences (Redshift, Background Radiation, Abundance) support the Big Bang Theory.

DDE694CEFBFF4DFFBF88BC35E812E171.description: Describe Cosmic Abundances of Light Elements

10C6C016B4544C489815B973501969BC.description:
Construct an evidence supported explanation for the Big Bang theory based on: 
Light spectra
Motion of galaxies 
Elemental composition of the Universe

229C923938C049CE8B2A2A2FB9BF1F91.description: Construct an explanation of the Big Bang theory based on astronomical evidence of light spectra, motion of distant galaxies, and composition of matter in the universe. [AR Clarification Statement: Emphasis is on dark energy, accelerating cosmic expansion, Hubble's law, and the discovery of the expansion of the universe. Examples of evidence could include cosmic abundances of light elements, the red shift found in galactic spectra, and cosmic microwave background radiation.]

924791BF203A40CFACCB9A657D64FF2A.description: Identify the elements a star will form through fusion given its initial mass.

5F062E50EF14462D95B6DE6CA90DB72E.description: Describe mass's effect on the elements produced

D70F11DB15D544E395913ED95D1A0922.description: Communicate scientific ideas about the way stars, over their lifecycle, produce elements

E570C2DD5EC94748B17D6095B6F930BC.description: Communicate scientific ideas about the way stars, over their lifecycle, produce elements. [AR Clarification Statement: Emphasis is on the fusion process and the production of elements of atomic #2 (helium) - #26 (iron); elements more massive than iron are produced only during a supernova event at the end of a star's life.]

E3477319924C4E6A9EADF72AD36E7327.description: Identify the route a star's life cycle will take given its initial mass

B0CCC6C84BB94148A2426403A875EA6D.description: Describe mass's effect on a star's evolution

FC339D9BC1B546718BB8D5249A0E72B1.description: Construct an explanation of how a star’s initial mass and elemental composition determine its lifecycle

0B89CD5391AD4C31AD4286F0819D9F71.description: Construct an explanation of how a star's initial mass uniquely determines the conditions that affect stability and factors that control rates of change over its lifetime. [Clarification Statement: Emphasis is on how initial mass determines the life cycle of a star as described by the Russell-Vogt theorem.]

0618D51A05F84D3FB570322A7A380219.description: Describe the Death and Remnants of Stars

3B6B814E60224E4C86B75A24C822210D.description: Describe the Old Age Stage of Stars

29F42A67CB4346B883EB225C555793FC.description: Use HR Diagrams to identify the Star Group Classifcation

DFBFB9813FCD435993F7D5859D7DB102.description: Develop a model based on evidence to illustrate the lifecycle of the Sun and other stars

8003CA0233F6465B9F7A4A11E8FC8F91.description: Develop a model based on evidence to illustrate the lifespan of the sun and the role of nuclear fusion in the sun's core to release energy in the form of radiation. [AR Clarification Statement: Emphasis is on developing a model based on evidence to illustrate the lifespan of the sun.]

A9C62A476E0B4AB2AC4A89BFA2559C76.description: Analyze a major global challenge to specify qualitative and quantitative criteria and  constraints for solutions that account for societal needs and wants. [AR Clarification Statement: Possible major global challenges could include disruptions to communication and navigational networks including satellites and land-based communications or use and design of night vision goggles that convert electromagnetic radiation beyond the visible range into useful information.]

3C8CC7D554594BB0A27817D334AED3FF.description: Describe how Spectroscopy can be used to determine elemental composition of stars

D1EAF1E589F04859B130F11642FABDFB.description: Identify elements based on Spectrometric Signatures

8CE2CB14091C4D408F2705D02C1624DA.description: Conduct an investigation that explores how light acts like a particle

63BC41E10C8E404FAA173E5E35A2BCF5.description: Plan and conduct an investigation that demonstrates how the particle-like nature of light produced by the Sun and other stars can carry information related to chemical composition

1ECC45A9C7544F3C8327FCAB6AA9C7F3.description: Describe how Doppler Shift can be used to determine the motion of stars

2D99A4B6424B44A1B87D71067185BBD8.description: Identify the motion of a star based on its Doppler Shift

7979BC9F08E249D3861955CBBAD5B54A.description: Identify the temperature of a star based on the light of its color

D5E5017058984734892845136172994C.description: Conduct an investigation that explores how light acts like a wave

D45A452949D743978EA3278C5814E93C.description: Plan and conduct an investigation that demonstrates how the wave-like nature of light produced by the Sun and other stars can carry information related to temperature and motion

F6B92F70FADE4699845140407FF933AF.description: Plan and carry out investigations to demonstrate the dual nature of light as a wave and particle that transmits energy and information about the nature and motion of the matter that emitted it. [Clarification Statement: Emphasis is on the wave and particle nature of light, including the entire range of the electromagnetic spectrum, the use of spectroscopy to investigate the composition of matter, and the use of Doppler shift to determine the relative motion of stars and galaxies.]

8D5D988B3E19452CA6693E941A4AC14C.description: Describe how the fusion process in a star relates to the energy released by the star.

151153E96EC14E14B14314363D1CE4FE.description: Model a nuclear fusion process found in a star (i.e. Proton-Proton Chain, Triple Alpha Process, CNO Cycle)

9AFE17D4AB4F42E182F986490179ABA8.description: Develop an evidence supported model of nuclear fusion occurring in the Sun and all other stars

692D2F1F088F437DA2F069D5DE8D32D0.description: Develop a model based on evidence to illustrate the lifespan of the sun and the role of nuclear fusion in the sun's core to release energy in the form of radiation. [AR Clarification Statement: This PE is partially addressed in this topic. Emphasis is on the role of nuclear fusion in the sun's core producing radiant energy that reaches out into space and carries information about the sun's composition, temperature, and other physical processes.]

37520F4ABD334C9E916981FD6AC7152A.description: Predict Solar weather based on various sunspot variables

641C0C744D1B4518A2272A2686A2C826.description: Analyze data to find patterns in Sunspot activity

47C8B1DAC7074ECAACAAE2FE937B455D.description: Describe the following Solar Phenomenon: Sunspots, Solar Flares, Solar Prominences, Solar Wind, Active Regions, and Coronal Mass Ejections

F4AEE5DD21104C47BFDE1131499E1BBB.description:
Create a model that can predict and explain the following solar phenomena: 
Solar magnetism 
Sunspots 
Solar flares 
CME
Solar prominences
Solar wind

CF7582A17900415ABD20CBB84564B376.description: Develop a model based on evidence to illustrate the lifespan of the sun and the role of nuclear fusion in the sun's core to release energy in the form of radiation. [AR Clarification Statement: This PE is partially addressed in this topic. Emphasis is on magnetic processes in the sun and their effects on the solar surface and space weather.]

70383D350040429B82B68A7137EC0657.description: Predict seasons on other planets given their orbital position and tilt.

CB0B85310D684C28969F19324E89CBE1.description: Describe the effect of Tilt, Aphelion, and Perihelion

7EEE1D87A1594EC796B8DC3A41FA77AF.description: Find Patterns in Temperature, Daylight Hours, Position of the Sun and Earth, and the Seasons

C76F4BC6B37440FC8692031D80104A88.description: Conduct an investigation to demonstrate how orbital positions and solar energy distribution can explain planetary seasons

32DDF45303C2443692F3BBC25960E5F6.description: Relate the Position/Phase of the moon and Sun to Spring and Neap Tides

BDEA813C77AF4494ABC883E4FBC12507.description: Relate the Position/Phase of the moon to High and Low Tides

0460092D35BB47C09BB707B0499347BB.description: Collect Tidal data and phases of the moon to determine a relationship

7ECFC52161574242938285DFA1794493.description: Develop an investigation to collect data related to the Moon and Tides

2283FDA9614F4B2582CF801F16139297.description: Conduct an investigation to demonstrate how orbital positions can explain tides

175B15AD04394D4983370D6156CA406A.description: Plan and carry out investigations to demonstrate how relative orbital positions of the Earth, Moon, and sun influence energy and matter flow into and out of a system to create tides and seasons, orbital angles between Earth, Moon, and sun create these effects. [Clarification Statement: Emphasis is on identifying positional relationships that produce tides on Earth (e.g., spring and neap tides, lunar perigee and apogee). Emphasis is also on positional relationships that produce seasons on Earth and other planets (e.g., axial tilt, perihelion, aphelion).]

31BA984AC99348598A5E6D13DF0509D2.description: Relate the Ecliptic position of the moon to eclipses

A1C763B7AAF84729BB4B099AC9B69DC1.description: Relate the Phase position of the moon to eclipses

6FFF669109A54C4A823F1FA01A81AB42.description: Relate the position of the moon to its phases

A5D82E43260642B9A8CF66E44A5F2C1C.description: Identify the phases of the moon

A252DB45A9104C14A40D466A54F180C3.description: Form a Hypothesis to questions about lunar eclipses

A11C64D94A6B41EE95010A4096C5243E.description: Form a Hypothesis to questions about lunar phases

78AB8A07593B44339D6ECE9ADD016E09.description: Form and test hypotheses related to the positional nature of lunar phases and eclipses

439FFD117D5F4C979F4FFE526F400AB9.description: Ask questions about relationships among the Earth, Moon, and sun to clarify the patterns of orbital positions that produce lunar phases and eclipses. [Clarification Statement: Emphasis is on the positional nature of the lunar phases, including solar and lunar eclipses, and how orbital angles between Earth, Moon, and sun create these effects.]

8CCEB65CE2944A02B1D01BD7C916191A.description: Describe evidence the supports or refutes various theories of hypothesis related to Earth's Early History

FB24BEAFDC5E48EDB817870140C9182D.description: Analyze evidence to determine patterns in Earth's History

FD85266CE9D84C789EC524F1A33EF9E1.description:
Construct an evidence supported explanation of Earth’s formation and early history using radiometric and other data related to: 
Earth materials,  Meteorites,  Lunar & Martian rocks

3FB6A76365774A66BD37F4167EB1200F.description: Apply scientific reasoning and evidence from ancient Earth materials, meteorites, and other planetary surfaces to construct an account of Earth's formation and early history. [AR Clarification Statement: Emphasis is on evidence found on other planetary, lunar, and meteoric surfaces. Evidence could include detection of water, composition of materials, geological activity, and the evolution of planetary surfaces.]

CF533FC72EA44BEB93D81D5190146058.description: Develop a scale of the light year and relate objects on that scale

51E303236BC94115AA34D50CEF4FDCE8.description: Define the Light Year and Parsec

E8EBC3F44963454295686D9C84709AEF.description: Develop a scale of the Astronomical unit and relate objects on that scale

4FF774C2F9404FABA6EEC0BD587449DD.description: Use correct notation and units when describing things on a Star System Scale

CF732A446DC74CF7912DC10AFBFA4A22.description: Convert into and out of Scientific Notation

C3E6AA23C051483BBE1B7CB16005D290.description: Use correct notation and units when describing things on a Planetary Scale

52396AF6962F4BB796DEE60E6809D9B0.description: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information about patterns of size and scale of the solar system, our galaxy, and the universe. [Clarification Statement: Emphasis is on the differences in solar, galactic, and universal distance and size scales using both qualitative and quantitative tools including scientific notation, appropriate astronomical units, light years, and parsecs.]

720BD53EEC0040A2B21845546219F606.description: Describe the process of Asteroid Formation

175458730AB646C1B5BFDD826765F47B.description: Use Observational Data to Describe the possible regions of planetary formation

07F0175EC59540888451216EC68E9671.description:
Using data related to protoplanetary disks, describe how planetary systems can form distinct regions using data related to: 
Terrestrial planets 
Jovian planets 
Asteroid belts

E1AAB7CB50F24466A287863952E12EBA.description: Use Observational Data to Support Explanations of Planetary Formation

BB7DC07A973840B0BFB8553AC7CC37A6.description: Identify the various stages of planetary formation

8A1E2B4FF540464B8E8F1401BFD57D76.description: Describe teh Conditions for Planetary Formation

18020B80012E482AB60E12038077877C.description:
Describe how nebular theory results in planet formation using data related to: 
Protoplanetary disks 
Exoplanets

F12AB550EE5A4CFAB32D8D27ECC9E450.description: Use Observational Data to Support Explanations of Stellar Formation

BA4632EDFD544827A5B476914BB871FB.description: Identify the various stages of Stellar Formation

F9F3C6F6E72149088FDEA155E8B4E79D.description: Describe the Conditions for Stellar Formation

5A3360DE312746558A8D98C3998166EB.description:
Describe how nebular theory results in star formation using data related to: 
Stellar nurseries or molecular clouds
Young stellar objects 
Pre-main sequence stars

33AA92AA6AA0465FAB59249DFA0A2B13.description: Using Data, describe how nebular theory results in star formation and planet formation

674E0A37EF654A61893F2134C74D50B9.description: Analyze and interpret data to describe how nebular theory and gravitational collapse result in star and solar system formation with distinct regions characterized by different types of planetary and other bodies. [Clarification Statement: Emphasis is on the origin and development of Laplace’s nebular theory. Emphasis is also on regions of the solar system including the inner and outer solar system and the habitable.]

5D418D15F9854A1899410294F093E1B5.description: Construct and use a mathematical model or models, related to the conservation of momentum, to describe linear motion of objects in our Solar System.

203B18FDFEF246BB86A850DDF96A6E3F.description: Construct and use a mathematical model or models, related to Newton’s 2nd Law, to describe linear motion of objects in our Solar System.

EB1ABED3969C4F3BA563BCF347A34A49.description: Use a computer simulation to model the impact of proposed solutions to a complex real-world problem with numerous criteria and constraints on interactions within and between systems  relevant to the problem. [AR Clarification Statement: Real-world problems could include launching a satellite into geosynchronous orbit or safely landing an orbital vehicle on the surface of a planet or moon. Criteria and constraints could include the mass of the vessel, gravitational conditions on different planets and moons, fuel, materials used, starting position, and velocity vectors.]

7A9B5D7813AA43929DE778C2298CD8A9.description:
Construct an explanation of how gravity influences planetary structure including: 
differentiation of interior
ring formation
moon formation
atmosphere

62FECE846417488F9B85EFEF09C9F462.description: Construct an explanation of how Newton’s Law of Universal Gravitation is influenced by mass, density and radius.

A3ED1D058AA948F5B09C458D137935DD.description: Construct an explanation of how gravitational forces are influenced by mass, density, and radius and how these forces impact the evolution of planetary structure, surfaces, atmospheres, and rings. [Clarification Statement: Emphasis is on how gravitational forces cause changes in planetary structure, including differentiation of the interior and mediation of ring and moon formation.]

02D520F85CE946138B21DBA6361CB877.description: Compare the rotational mathematical models for solar systems, galaxies and galactic clusters to demonstrate how the properties of these structures scale.

C09C89F9442F47419414225FEB1B1616.description: Use mathematics and computational thinking to demonstrate rotationally dynamic systems and how these structures scale from solar systems to galaxies to bound galactic  clusters.[Clarification Statement: Emphasis is on the use of mathematical models of rotationally dynamic systems to apply Newton's laws of gravitation and Kepler's laws of planetary motion.]

D1CD1B1CA87049EE9F638F90027E0701.description: Construct and use a mathematical model or models, related to the conservation of momentum, to describe rotational motion of objects in our Solar System.

CB8ADC6165DE407ABEA6FF5362E0F770.description: Construct and use a mathematical model or models, related to Newton’s 2nd Law, to describe rotational motion of objects in our Solar System.

E8ABF44BD5F94F7DAFD0AE2B97FF66CF.description: Use mathematical or computational representations to predict the motion of orbiting objects in the solar system. [AR Clarification Statement: Emphasis is on applying Kepler's laws of elliptical planetary motion to determine how gravitation affects planetary orbits and orbital velocity.]

42FC4424AA8A476796EE22C3D44141F7.description:
Using student derived evidence for support, construct explanations as to how the telescope led to the transition from the geocentric model of Aristotle and Ptolemy to heliocentric model of Copernicus from Galilean observations: 
Venus’ phases,  Jupiter’s Moons,  Sunspots,  The Moon’s craters

D7040C7D1D984163BB94D57F54FB0882.description: Construct explanations of how the telescope impacted the evolution of solar system models from geocentric to heliocentric. [Clarification Statement: Emphasis is on the development of the geocentric model by Aristotle and Ptolemy to the development of the Copernican astronomical model which was facilitated by Galileo’s telescopic astronomy.]

F7A75591A3DF410E8152E8102BBD3624.description: Using student derived evidence for support, construct arguments and counterarguments related to pre-telescopic cultures and the influence of astronomical related phenomenon on their cultures use of navigation.

875AB288D8CF43EF926AFF91C00599EA.description: Using student derived evidence for support, construct arguments and counterarguments related to pre-telescopic cultures and the influence of astronomical related phenomenon on their cultures use of time keeping.

93EB8C84DC9F4502A4B58B6412640698.description: Engage in arguments from evidence about how the development of astronomy in the pre-telescopic age laid the groundwork for modern astronomy. [Clarification Statement: Emphasis is on development and cultural importance of time keeping, navigation, and measurement of the Earth-Moon system.]

318228B95D844C2F9AA128A14D1A342C.description: Test Solution and collect evidence on its viability

47A99558D73349249789826B4C896A16.description: Develop a solution to a cause of light pollution

25B968249FA24821A75014EBDFA989B9.description: Identify possible sources of light pollution

FB7330A2E10446B7B5EED60B1AE0CE2C.description: Develop an investigation to determine the effect of light pollution in the local area

45F95905B5BC4AF58FBB58F245FF5678.description: Design a solution for local light pollution and its effects on astronomical viewing by collecting evidence that supports the solution’s components. [Accessible aspects of the design cycle include: defining,  criteria, constraints and optimization]

2101A4D349E346F088A981187BA3F033.description: Design a solution to a complex real world problem by breaking it down into smaller, more manageable problems that can be solved through engineering. [AR Clarification Statement: A possible real world problem would be to design a way to reduce local light pollution to facilitate the observation of the night sky.]

F6DE2AB7B90948F5AFE71323B3A90B69.description: Describe the Brightness of Objects using Magntitude

581402FEAC9A4AA2B2187C4ABD6EE89E.description: Describe the Position of Objects using Right Ascension and Declination

1E01483EC25145D697F3214292FAB72B.description: Describe the Position of Objects using Altitude and Azimuth

1AD693C38DB14A968E506EA53A3D9B6C.description: Using previous observations along with star map and planisphere observations, construct an oral/written response that describes how magnitude, color and position (RaDec and AltAz) is used to classify celestial objects.

CC49C7D791CE4AC9BA441406ECEB59E6.description: Obtain, evaluate, and communicate information gathered from observational evidence, maps,  and charts to demonstrate an understanding of the ecliptic patterns, magnitudes, and colors of stars, and the dynamic locations of constellations, asterisms, and planets. [Clarification Statement: Students use both major coordinate systems (Right Ascension/Declination, Altitude/Azimuth). Students account for the independent dynamic motions of the planets, Moon, and sun in contrast with the fixed nature of constellations.

D05842D084A04B3E9989F813B8E09421.description: Relate the motion of celestial objects to the Ecliptic

1EF3A2319CE441E1854B0DAD983ACF3F.description: Describe what objects are found on the ecliptic

74FBF2921C6B400EA07715904013A889.description:
Using previous observations along with star map and planisphere observations, construct an oral/written response that describes ecliptic patterns which include: 
Motion of individual planets,,  Motion of the Moon,  Motion of the Sun.

66C4DAA43D974506AADBE562228904F5.description: Illustrate the Seasonal movement of Celestial Objects on the Celestial Sphere Model at a given latitude

E603261BDA454D61A22E7BEF3CFBEEB5.description: Using planetarium simulation and naked eye/binocular observations, create 2-D celestial sphere model that predicts seasonal patterns of the Moon, the Sun, planets and/or constellations.

FE39511D5F9A489CB422522EBB061B06.description: Use the Celestial Sphere Model to predict the diurnal motion of Celestial Objects based on the Latitude of the Observer

7B281EF725EA457F8AB77C5AF8EAA1E8.description: Illustrate the movement of Celestial Objects on the Celestial Sphere Model at a given latitude

34D9BA7C10A44751A3E8D05BBA57EFBE.description: Draw a Dirunal Celestial Sphere Model

A4C116620BDA4ABFB52F10804800FE31.description: Using planetarium simulation and naked eye/binocular observations, create a 2-D celestial sphere model that predicts diurnal patterns of the Moon, the Sun, planets and constellations.

ADAE1E1D6CBD45FAB079F17CBB3A2962.description: Develop a model using observational evidence that accounts for patterns in diurnal, seasonal, and annual movements of objects on the celestial sphere. [Clarification Statement: Students record observations of the night sky or use observational data from computer models
